# CLAUDE.md This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository. # JobJoy Assessment Platform Development Guide ## Project Overview This is a React/TypeScript job satisfaction assessment platform with Firebase backend. Users complete multi-dimensional assessments and receive personalized coaching insights through interactive radar chart visualizations. **Key Technologies:** - Frontend: React 18 + TypeScript + Vite - UI: Tailwind CSS + Radix UI components (shadcn/ui) - Charts: Recharts for radar visualization - Backend: Firebase (Auth, Firestore, Storage) - Testing: Jest + Vitest + React Testing Library - State: React Context + TanStack Query ## Core Philosophy - **Pre-phase Planning**: Always formulate and discuss plans before implementation - **Minimal Code**: Lines of code = Technical debt. Write less, achieve more - **Security First**: Never expose secrets, always implement proper authentication - **Type Safety**: Use TypeScript with strict typing across all projects - **Modular Architecture**: 150-line file limit, extract when approaching limit ## Universal Coding Standards ### File Organization - Directories: lowercase with dashes (e.g., `user-profile`) - Components: PascalCase (e.g., `UserProfile.tsx`) - Utilities: camelCase (e.g., `formatDate.ts`) - Types: Separate `.types.ts` files for shared types - Keep related files together in feature folders ### Code Style - Functional programming over OOP - Early returns for readability - RORO pattern for functions with multiple parameters - Descriptive variable names over comments - Explicit over implicit ### Error Handling ```typescript // Always use Result pattern for operations that can fail type Result = { success: true; data: T } | { success: false; error: E }; ``` ### Git Workflow - Descriptive commit messages focusing on "why" not "what" - Small, atomic commits - Never commit commented-out code - Use .gitignore properly ## Mem0 Integration When persistent memory is needed: 1. Reference existing memories with @mem0 2. Update memories after significant implementations 3. Store project-specific patterns and decisions ## Security Principles - Never hardcode secrets or API keys - Use environment variables with proper validation - Implement proper authentication before any data access - Always use HTTPS in production - Sanitize all user inputs ## Testing Philosophy - Write tests for business logic - Integration tests over unit tests when practical - Test the behavior, not the implementation - Use descriptive test names that explain the scenario ## Documentation Standards - Document "why" not "what" in code - Keep README files updated with setup instructions - API documentation should include examples - Complex algorithms need explanation comments ## Pre-Phase Planning Template Before any implementation: 1. State the objective clearly 2. List technical requirements 3. Identify potential challenges 4. Propose implementation approach 5. Get confirmation before proceeding ## Development Workflow 1. Understand the full context first 2. Plan the implementation approach 3. Implement in small, testable increments 4. Verify each step works before proceeding 5. Refactor if approaching complexity limits ## Performance Considerations - Lazy load when possible - Optimize images and assets - Use proper caching strategies - Monitor bundle sizes - Profile before optimizing ## Accessibility Standards - Semantic HTML elements - Proper ARIA labels when needed - Keyboard navigation support - Color contrast compliance - Screen reader testing ## Mobile Content Alignment Procedure ### Header-Aware Vertical Centering Pattern For full-screen assessment components that need proper vertical centering while accounting for header presence: ```tsx // Container structure for mobile-optimized centering
{/* Top spacer - reduced for header compensation */}
{/* Main content container */}
{/* Assessment content here */}
{/* Bottom spacer - normal flex */}
``` ### Key Principles: - **Container**: `h-screen flex flex-col overflow-hidden` prevents scrolling - **Top spacer**: `flex-[0.8]` takes 80% of normal flex space (44.4% of available) - **Bottom spacer**: `flex-1` takes 100% of normal flex space (55.6% of available) - **Content**: `flex-shrink-0 flex-grow-0` maintains natural size - **Result**: Content appears centered in content area below header ### Page-Level No-Scroll Setup: ```tsx // Page wrapper to prevent scrolling
{/* Navigation buttons */}
{/* Assessment component */}
``` ### Benefits: - ✅ No scrolling capability on mobile devices - ✅ Content positioned optimally for viewing - ✅ Header height automatically compensated - ✅ Responsive across all mobile screen sizes - ✅ Consistent visual balance Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions. ## Comprehensive Code Documentation Pattern ### Self-Documenting Code Standard All code must be written with extensive inline documentation that explains **what**, **why**, and **how** to modify elements. Follow the JobValueCompass component pattern as the gold standard. ### Documentation Requirements #### 1. Component-Level Documentation ```tsx // --- // HOW TO EDIT THE SIZE OF THE WHOLE RADAR CHART? // --- // The size of the radar chart is controlled by two main things: // 1. The height of the container div (e.g. className="h-[350px]") // - This controls the vertical space for the chart. Increase/decrease the h-[XXXpx] value to make the chart area taller or shorter. // 2. The `outerRadius` prop on the component (e.g. outerRadius="60%") // - This controls the radius of the radar chart as a percentage of the container. Increase to make the chart fill more of the container, decrease for more padding. // // To make the chart bigger or smaller, change the value of the container's height // and/or the `outerRadius` prop. Both are set separately for mobile and desktop below. // --- ``` #### 2. Style Property Documentation Every style-related element must include comprehensive comments explaining: - **Purpose**: What the style does - **Values**: What values can be used - **Effect**: How changing it affects the appearance - **Examples**: Alternative values and their effects ```tsx
{/* backdrop-blur-xl: Applies a strong background blur. Change to "backdrop-blur-md" for less blur, or remove for no blur. bg-white/10: Sets a white background with 10% opacity. Change the number for more/less opacity. border border-white/20: Adds a border with 20% white opacity. Change to "border-black/10" for a different color/opacity. shadow-2xl: Applies a large shadow. Change to "shadow-lg" for a smaller shadow, or remove for no shadow. rounded-2xl: Rounds the corners. Change to "rounded-lg" for less rounding, or remove for square corners. p-6: Padding inside the container. Change to "p-4" for less padding, "p-8" for more. */}
``` #### 3. Interactive Element Documentation For components with user interaction, document: - **Function**: What the element does - **Customization**: How to modify behavior - **Styling**: How to change appearance - **State**: How it responds to different states ```tsx // --- STYLE ELEMENTS IN THIS COMPONENT --- // - fontSize: Controls the size of the category label text. Change the value (e.g. "10" or "12") to make labels smaller or larger. // - fill: Controls the color of the label text. Change "#374151" to any hex color for different text color. // - fontWeight: Controls the boldness of the label text. "600" is semi-bold; use "400" for normal, "700" for bold. // - fontFamily: Controls the font used for the labels. Change to any valid CSS font-family string. // - letterSpacing: Controls the spacing between letters. Adjust "-0.01em" for tighter/looser text. // - radius: Controls how far the labels are from the center of the chart. Increase for more space between chart and labels. // - xOffset: Controls horizontal offset for left/right labels. Adjust for fine-tuning label position. // ---------------------------------------- ``` #### 4. Responsive Design Documentation Document how elements behave across different screen sizes: ```tsx {isMobile ? ( // To change the mobile chart size, edit the h-[300px] class and/or outerRadius below
{/* h-[300px]: Height of the chart area. Increase/decrease for bigger/smaller chart. w-full: Full width. opacity-40: 40% opacity for the whole chart (makes it look "greyed out"). Change to "opacity-60" for less faded, "opacity-20" for more faded. */} ) : ( // To change the desktop chart size, edit the h-[350px] class and/or outerRadius below
)} ``` #### 5. Configuration Object Documentation For configuration objects, explain each property: ```tsx const categoryNames: Record = { // These control the display names for each category in the radar chart // Change the values on the right to customize how categories appear purpose: 'Purpose', // Shows as "Purpose" on the chart growth: 'Growth', // Shows as "Growth" on the chart compensation: 'Compensation', // Shows as "Compensation" on the chart // ... etc }; ``` #### 6. Complex Logic Documentation For complex calculations or logic, provide step-by-step explanations: ```tsx // Calculate angle from center const angle = Math.atan2(y - cy, x - cx); // Position label at fixed radius // Change these values to move labels closer/farther from the chart const radius = isMobile ? 65 : 110; const newX = cx + Math.cos(angle) * radius; const newY = cy + Math.sin(angle) * radius; // Smart anchoring to prevent cutoff // This logic determines text alignment based on position around the circle if (angleInDegrees > 60 && angleInDegrees < 120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Bottom labels } else if (angleInDegrees < -60 && angleInDegrees > -120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Top labels } // ... etc ``` ### Documentation Standards #### Required Documentation Blocks: 1. **File Header**: Brief description of component purpose 2. **HOW TO EDIT**: Major customization instructions at the top 3. **Style Elements**: Inline comments for every style property 4. **Configuration**: Explanation of all configurable values 5. **Logic**: Step-by-step explanation of complex operations 6. **Responsive**: Mobile vs desktop differences #### Documentation Format: - Use `// ---` separators for major sections - Use `/* */` for multi-line style explanations - Use `//` for single-line clarifications - Include specific examples with alternative values - Explain the visual/functional impact of changes #### Mandatory Elements to Document: - All Tailwind CSS classes with their purpose and alternatives - All props and their acceptable values - All configuration objects and their properties - All complex calculations or positioning logic - All responsive breakpoints and their differences - All interactive elements and their behaviors ### Benefits of This Pattern: - **Self-Sufficient**: Developers can modify without external documentation - **Educational**: Teaches CSS/styling concepts through examples - **Maintainable**: Changes are easier when effects are understood - **Collaborative**: Team members can quickly understand and modify code - **Future-Proof**: Code remains understandable months/years later ### Implementation Rule: Every component must be documented to the level where a developer unfamiliar with the codebase can: 1. Understand what each element does 2. Know exactly how to modify appearance/behavior 3. See examples of alternative configurations 4. Understand responsive behavior differences ## Responsive Code Structure Best Practices ### Preferred Approach: Mobile-First Responsive Classes Use Tailwind's responsive prefixes instead of JavaScript conditionals when possible: ```tsx // ✅ PREFERRED: Single component with responsive classes
``` ### When to Use JavaScript Conditionals: Only use separate mobile/desktop code blocks when: - **Fundamentally different layouts** are required - **Complex logic** differs significantly between devices - **Performance optimization** requires different components ### Structure for JS Conditionals (when necessary): ```tsx export const Component = () => { // --- SHARED CONFIGURATION --- const sharedProps = { /* common props */ }; // --- MOBILE CONFIGURATION --- const mobileConfig = { /* mobile-specific settings */ }; // --- DESKTOP CONFIGURATION --- const desktopConfig = { /* desktop-specific settings */ }; // --- RESPONSIVE LOGIC --- const isMobile = useMediaQuery('(max-width: 640px)'); const config = isMobile ? mobileConfig : desktopConfig; return (
{/* Single implementation using config */}
); }; ``` ### Avoid: - ❌ Duplicating entire component trees for different devices - ❌ Separate mobile/desktop returns with identical JSX - ❌ Hard-coded breakpoints in multiple places ### Benefits of Mobile-First Approach: - **Less code duplication** - **Easier maintenance** - **Better performance** (CSS-based vs JS-based) - **More flexible** (handles all breakpoints, not just 2) - **Future-proof** (new devices automatically supported) Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions. ## 🔄 CODEBASE REFACTORING INSTRUCTIONS ### Mobile-First Responsive Design + Self-Documenting Code Implementation **Target:** Transform the entire codebase to follow the JobValueCompass pattern established in `src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx` --- ## 📋 PHASE 1: AUDIT & PLANNING ### Step 1.1: Identify Components Requiring Refactoring Search for these patterns that need conversion: ```bash # Find JavaScript-based responsive conditionals grep -r "window.innerWidth" src/ grep -r "isMobile" src/ grep -r "useMediaQuery" src/ grep -r "typeof window" src/ # Find components with duplicate mobile/desktop code grep -r "if.*mobile" src/ -i grep -r "else.*desktop" src/ -i ``` ### Step 1.2: Component Priority List **High Priority (Core UI Components):** 1. Header.tsx 2. Logo.tsx 3. AssessmentForm.tsx 4. ResultsChart.tsx 5. All components in `/pages/` **Medium Priority (Feature Components):** 6. All components in `/components/auth/` 7. All components in `/components/ui/` 8. All components in `/components/storage/` **Low Priority (Utility Components):** 9. BackgroundWrapper.tsx 10. ErrorBoundary.tsx --- ## 📱 PHASE 2: MOBILE-FIRST CONVERSION PATTERNS ### Pattern A: Replace JavaScript Conditionals with Responsive Classes **❌ BEFORE (JavaScript-based):** ```tsx const isMobile = typeof window !== 'undefined' && window.innerWidth < 640; if (isMobile) { return (
{/* Mobile content */}
); } return (
{/* Desktop content */}
); ``` **✅ AFTER (Mobile-first responsive):** ```tsx // Single implementation with responsive classes
{/* h-[300px] sm:h-[350px] lg:h-[400px]: Responsive height - h-[300px]: Mobile height (300px) - sm:h-[350px]: Tablet and up height (350px) - lg:h-[400px]: Desktop and up height (400px) p-4 sm:p-6: Responsive padding - p-4: Mobile padding (16px) - sm:p-6: Tablet+ padding (24px) To make bigger/smaller: - Increase heights: h-[350px] sm:h-[400px] lg:h-[450px] - Decrease heights: h-[250px] sm:h-[300px] lg:h-[350px] */} {/* Same content for all devices */}
``` ### Pattern B: Responsive Text Content **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx {isMobile ? "Short text" : "This is a longer descriptive text"} ``` **✅ AFTER:** ```tsx {/* Show different text based on screen size using responsive classes */} Short text This is a longer descriptive text ``` ### Pattern C: Responsive Component Props **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx

## Mobile Content Alignment Procedure ### Header-Aware Vertical Centering Pattern For full-screen assessment components that need proper vertical centering while accounting for header presence: ```tsx // Container structure for mobile-optimized centering
{/* Top spacer - reduced for header compensation */}
{/* Main content container */}
{/* Assessment content here */}
{/* Bottom spacer - normal flex */}
``` ### Key Principles: - **Container**: `h-screen flex flex-col overflow-hidden` prevents scrolling - **Top spacer**: `flex-[0.8]` takes 80% of normal flex space (44.4% of available) - **Bottom spacer**: `flex-1` takes 100% of normal flex space (55.6% of available) - **Content**: `flex-shrink-0 flex-grow-0` maintains natural size - **Result**: Content appears centered in content area below header ### Page-Level No-Scroll Setup: ```tsx // Page wrapper to prevent scrolling
{/* Navigation buttons */}
{/* Assessment component */}
``` ### Benefits: - ✅ No scrolling capability on mobile devices - ✅ Content positioned optimally for viewing - ✅ Header height automatically compensated - ✅ Responsive across all mobile screen sizes - ✅ Consistent visual balance Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions.
input.new_string:
## Firebase Integration

**Environment Variables Required:**
```bash
VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY=your-api-key
VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN=your-auth-domain
VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID=your-project-id
VITE_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET=your-storage-bucket
VITE_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID=your-messaging-sender-id
VITE_FIREBASE_APP_ID=your-app-id
```

**Key Firebase Files:**
- `src/firebase/config.ts` - Firebase app initialization
- `src/firebase/auth.ts` - Authentication functions
- `src/firebase/firestore.ts` - Database operations
- `src/firebase/storage.ts` - File storage operations
- `firestore.rules` - Database security rules
- `storage.rules` - Storage security rules

**Important Notes:**
- Uses Firebase-first architecture (prefer Firebase over localStorage)
- All Firebase operations include error handling
- Security rules enforce user authentication for data access

## Testing Strategy

**Test Organization:**
- Unit tests: Business logic in `/utils/__tests__/`
- Component tests: React components in `__tests__/` folders
- Integration tests: Firebase operations in `/src/__tests__/firebase/`

**Key Test Areas:**
- Assessment scoring calculations (`calculationCore.test.ts`)
- Firebase authentication flow
- Component rendering and user interactions
- Cross-device storage functionality

**Test Patterns:**
- Use descriptive test names that explain the scenario
- Mock Firebase services for isolated testing
- Test business logic separately from UI components

# CLAUDE.md This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository. # JobJoy Assessment Platform Development Guide ## Project Overview This is a React/TypeScript job satisfaction assessment platform with Firebase backend. Users complete multi-dimensional assessments and receive personalized coaching insights through interactive radar chart visualizations. **Key Technologies:** - Frontend: React 18 + TypeScript + Vite - UI: Tailwind CSS + Radix UI components (shadcn/ui) - Charts: Recharts for radar visualization - Backend: Firebase (Auth, Firestore, Storage) - Testing: Jest + Vitest + React Testing Library - State: React Context + TanStack Query ## Core Philosophy - **Pre-phase Planning**: Always formulate and discuss plans before implementation - **Minimal Code**: Lines of code = Technical debt. Write less, achieve more - **Security First**: Never expose secrets, always implement proper authentication - **Type Safety**: Use TypeScript with strict typing across all projects - **Modular Architecture**: 150-line file limit, extract when approaching limit ## Common Development Commands **Development:** ```bash npm run dev # Start development server (Vite) at http://localhost:5173 npm run dev:prod # Start dev server with production config ``` **Building:** ```bash npm run build # Build for production (automatically detects environment) npm run build:dev # Build with development config npm run build:prod # Build with production config npm run preview # Preview production build locally ``` **Testing:** ```bash npm test # Run Jest tests npm run test:watch # Run Jest in watch mode npm run test:vitest # Run Vitest tests npm run test:vitest:watch # Run Vitest in watch mode ``` **Linting & Code Quality:** ```bash npm run lint # Run ESLint ``` **Deployment:** ```bash npm run deploy # Build and deploy to Firebase (full deploy) npm run deploy:hosting # Build and deploy only hosting ./deploy.sh # Run deployment script with status output ``` **Firebase Emulators:** ```bash firebase emulators:start # Start all Firebase emulators # Emulator ports (from firebase.json): # - Auth: 9797 # - Firestore: 8785 # - Storage: 9798 # - Hosting: 5001 # - UI: 4700 ``` ## Project Architecture **Core Application Flow:** 1. **Landing Page** (`/pages/Index.tsx`) - Welcome and start assessment 2. **Assessment Phase** (`/pages/FirstStep.tsx`) - Job satisfaction rating (1-5 scale) 3. **Importance Phase** (`/pages/SecondStep.tsx`) - Importance weighting (optional, can be skipped) 4. **Results** (`/pages/ResultsEnhanced.tsx`) - Radar chart visualization and coaching **Key Architecture Patterns:** **State Management:** - React Context for auth (`/context/AuthContext.tsx`) - TanStack Query for server state - Local storage utilities for assessment data persistence - Cross-device storage system for assessment continuity **Component Organization:** ``` src/ ├── components/ # Reusable UI components │ ├── auth/ # Authentication-related components │ ├── results/ # Results visualization components │ ├── storage/ # File upload/download components │ └── ui/ # Base UI components (shadcn/ui) ├── pages/ # Route components (one per route) ├── context/ # React contexts (Auth, Firebase) ├── firebase/ # Firebase service functions ├── hooks/ # Custom React hooks ├── utils/ # Utility functions └── types/ # TypeScript type definitions ``` **Assessment Scoring System:** - Core logic in `src/utils/calculationCore.ts` - Produces scores from -88 to +88 - Handles both weighted (with importance) and unweighted modes - Includes "bother level" impact for negative satisfaction **Mobile-First Responsive Design:** - Uses Tailwind responsive classes (`sm:`, `lg:`) instead of JavaScript breakpoints - JobValueCompass component exemplifies best responsive patterns - Prevent scrolling on assessment pages with specific container patterns ## Mobile Content Alignment Procedure ### Header-Aware Vertical Centering Pattern For full-screen assessment components that need proper vertical centering while accounting for header presence: ```tsx // Container structure for mobile-optimized centering
{/* Top spacer - reduced for header compensation */}
{/* Main content container */}
{/* Assessment content here */}
{/* Bottom spacer - normal flex */}
``` ### Key Principles: - **Container**: `h-screen flex flex-col overflow-hidden` prevents scrolling - **Top spacer**: `flex-[0.8]` takes 80% of normal flex space (44.4% of available) - **Bottom spacer**: `flex-1` takes 100% of normal flex space (55.6% of available) - **Content**: `flex-shrink-0 flex-grow-0` maintains natural size - **Result**: Content appears centered in content area below header ### Page-Level No-Scroll Setup: ```tsx // Page wrapper to prevent scrolling
{/* Navigation buttons */}
{/* Assessment component */}
``` ### Benefits: - ✅ No scrolling capability on mobile devices - ✅ Content positioned optimally for viewing - ✅ Header height automatically compensated - ✅ Responsive across all mobile screen sizes - ✅ Consistent visual balance Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions. ## Comprehensive Code Documentation Pattern ### Self-Documenting Code Standard All code must be written with extensive inline documentation that explains **what**, **why**, and **how** to modify elements. Follow the JobValueCompass component pattern as the gold standard. ### Documentation Requirements #### 1. Component-Level Documentation ```tsx // --- // HOW TO EDIT THE SIZE OF THE WHOLE RADAR CHART? // --- // The size of the radar chart is controlled by two main things: // 1. The height of the container div (e.g. className="h-[350px]") // - This controls the vertical space for the chart. Increase/decrease the h-[XXXpx] value to make the chart area taller or shorter. // 2. The `outerRadius` prop on the component (e.g. outerRadius="60%") // - This controls the radius of the radar chart as a percentage of the container. Increase to make the chart fill more of the container, decrease for more padding. // // To make the chart bigger or smaller, change the value of the container's height // and/or the `outerRadius` prop. Both are set separately for mobile and desktop below. // --- ``` #### 2. Style Property Documentation Every style-related element must include comprehensive comments explaining: - **Purpose**: What the style does - **Values**: What values can be used - **Effect**: How changing it affects the appearance - **Examples**: Alternative values and their effects ```tsx
{/* backdrop-blur-xl: Applies a strong background blur. Change to "backdrop-blur-md" for less blur, or remove for no blur. bg-white/10: Sets a white background with 10% opacity. Change the number for more/less opacity. border border-white/20: Adds a border with 20% white opacity. Change to "border-black/10" for a different color/opacity. shadow-2xl: Applies a large shadow. Change to "shadow-lg" for a smaller shadow, or remove for no shadow. rounded-2xl: Rounds the corners. Change to "rounded-lg" for less rounding, or remove for square corners. p-6: Padding inside the container. Change to "p-4" for less padding, "p-8" for more. */}
``` #### 3. Interactive Element Documentation For components with user interaction, document: - **Function**: What the element does - **Customization**: How to modify behavior - **Styling**: How to change appearance - **State**: How it responds to different states ```tsx // --- STYLE ELEMENTS IN THIS COMPONENT --- // - fontSize: Controls the size of the category label text. Change "#374151" to any hex color for different text color. // - fontWeight: Controls the boldness of the label text. "600" is semi-bold; use "400" for normal, "700" for bold. // - fontFamily: Controls the font used for the labels. Increase for more space between chart and labels. // - xOffset: Controls horizontal offset for left/right labels. Change to "opacity-60" for less faded, "opacity-20" for more faded. */} ) : ( // To change the desktop chart size, edit the h-[350px] class and/or outerRadius below
)} ``` #### 5. {/* Single implementation using config */}
); }; ``` ### Avoid: - ❌ Duplicating entire component trees for different devices - ❌ Separate mobile/desktop returns with identical JSX - ❌ Hard-coded breakpoints in multiple places ### Benefits of Mobile-First Approach: - **Less code duplication** - **Easier maintenance** - **Better performance** (CSS-based vs JS-based) - **More flexible** (handles all breakpoints, not just 2) - **Future-proof** (new devices automatically supported) Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions. ## 🔄 CODEBASE REFACTORING INSTRUCTIONS ### Mobile-First Responsive Design + Self-Documenting Code Implementation **Target:** Transform the entire codebase to follow the JobValueCompass pattern established in `src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx` --- ## 📋 PHASE 1: AUDIT & PLANNING ### Step 1.1: Identify Components Requiring Refactoring Search for these patterns that need conversion: ```bash # Find JavaScript-based responsive conditionals grep -r "window.innerWidth" src/ grep -r "isMobile" src/ grep -r "useMediaQuery" src/ grep -r "typeof window" src/ # Find components with duplicate mobile/desktop code grep -r "if.*mobile" src/ -i grep -r "else.*desktop" src/ -i ``` ### Step 1.2: Component Priority List **High Priority (Core UI Components):** 1. Header.tsx 2. Logo.tsx 3. AssessmentForm.tsx 4. ResultsChart.tsx 5. All components in `/pages/` **Medium Priority (Feature Components):** 6. All components in `/components/auth/` 7. All components in `/components/ui/` 8. All components in `/components/storage/` **Low Priority (Utility Components):** 9. BackgroundWrapper.tsx 10. ErrorBoundary.tsx --- ## 📱 PHASE 2: MOBILE-FIRST CONVERSION PATTERNS ### Pattern A: Replace JavaScript Conditionals with Responsive Classes **❌ BEFORE (JavaScript-based):** ```tsx const isMobile = typeof window !== 'undefined' && window.innerWidth < 640; if (isMobile) { return (
{/* Mobile content */}
); } return (
{/* Desktop content */}
); ``` **✅ AFTER (Mobile-first responsive):** ```tsx // Single implementation with responsive classes

``` ### Pattern B: Responsive Text Content **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx {isMobile ? "Short text" : "This is a longer descriptive text"} ``` **✅ AFTER:** ```tsx {/* Show different text based on screen size using responsive classes */} Short text This is a longer descriptive text ``` ### Pattern C: Responsive Component Props **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx

# CLAUDE.md This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository. # JobJoy Assessment Platform Development Guide ## Project Overview This is a React/TypeScript job satisfaction assessment platform with Firebase backend. Users complete multi-dimensional assessments and receive personalized coaching insights through interactive radar chart visualizations. **Key Technologies:** - Frontend: React 18 + TypeScript + Vite - UI: Tailwind CSS + Radix UI components (shadcn/ui) - Charts: Recharts for radar visualization - Backend: Firebase (Auth, Firestore, Storage) - Testing: Jest + Vitest + React Testing Library - State: React Context + TanStack Query ## Core Philosophy - **Pre-phase Planning**: Always formulate and discuss plans before implementation - **Minimal Code**: Lines of code = Technical debt. Write less, achieve more - **Security First**: Never expose secrets, always implement proper authentication - **Type Safety**: Use TypeScript with strict typing across all projects - **Modular Architecture**: 150-line file limit, extract when approaching limit ## Common Development Commands **Development:** ```bash npm run dev # Start development server (Vite) at http://localhost:5173 npm run dev:prod # Start dev server with production config ``` **Building:** ```bash npm run build # Build for production (automatically detects environment) npm run build:dev # Build with development config npm run build:prod # Build with production config npm run preview # Preview production build locally ``` **Testing:** ```bash npm test # Run Jest tests npm run test:watch # Run Jest in watch mode npm run test:vitest # Run Vitest tests npm run test:vitest:watch # Run Vitest in watch mode ``` **Linting & Code Quality:** ```bash npm run lint # Run ESLint ``` **Deployment:** ```bash npm run deploy # Build and deploy to Firebase (full deploy) npm run deploy:hosting # Build and deploy only hosting ./deploy.sh # Run deployment script with status output ``` **Firebase Emulators:** ```bash firebase emulators:start # Start all Firebase emulators # Emulator ports (from firebase.json): # - Auth: 9797 # - Firestore: 8785 # - Storage: 9798 # - Hosting: 5001 # - UI: 4700 ``` ## Project Architecture **Core Application Flow:** 1. **Landing Page** (`/pages/Index.tsx`) - Welcome and start assessment 2. **Assessment Phase** (`/pages/FirstStep.tsx`) - Job satisfaction rating (1-5 scale) 3. **Importance Phase** (`/pages/SecondStep.tsx`) - Importance weighting (optional, can be skipped) 4. **Results** (`/pages/ResultsEnhanced.tsx`) - Radar chart visualization and coaching **Key Architecture Patterns:** **State Management:** - React Context for auth (`/context/AuthContext.tsx`) - TanStack Query for server state - Local storage utilities for assessment data persistence - Cross-device storage system for assessment continuity **Component Organization:** ``` src/ ├── components/ # Reusable UI components │ ├── auth/ # Authentication-related components │ ├── results/ # Results visualization components │ ├── storage/ # File upload/download components │ └── ui/ # Base UI components (shadcn/ui) ├── pages/ # Route components (one per route) ├── context/ # React contexts (Auth, Firebase) ├── firebase/ # Firebase service functions ├── hooks/ # Custom React hooks ├── utils/ # Utility functions └── types/ # TypeScript type definitions ``` **Assessment Scoring System:** - Core logic in `src/utils/calculationCore.ts` - Produces scores from -88 to +88 - Handles both weighted (with importance) and unweighted modes - Includes "bother level" impact for negative satisfaction **Mobile-First Responsive Design:** - Uses Tailwind responsive classes (`sm:`, `lg:`) instead of JavaScript breakpoints - JobValueCompass component exemplifies best responsive patterns - Prevent scrolling on assessment pages with specific container patterns ## Firebase Integration **Environment Variables Required:** ```bash VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY=your-api-key VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN=your-auth-domain VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID=your-project-id VITE_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET=your-storage-bucket VITE_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID=your-messaging-sender-id VITE_FIREBASE_APP_ID=your-app-id ``` **Key Firebase Files:** - `src/firebase/config.ts` - Firebase app initialization - `src/firebase/auth.ts` - Authentication functions - `src/firebase/firestore.ts` - Database operations - `src/firebase/storage.ts` - File storage operations - `firestore.rules` - Database security rules - `storage.rules` - Storage security rules **Important Notes:** - Uses Firebase-first architecture (prefer Firebase over localStorage) - All Firebase operations include error handling - Security rules enforce user authentication for data access ## Testing Strategy **Test Organization:** - Unit tests: Business logic in `/utils/__tests__/` - Component tests: React components in `__tests__/` folders - Integration tests: Firebase operations in `/src/__tests__/firebase/` **Key Test Areas:** - Assessment scoring calculations (`calculationCore.test.ts`) - Firebase authentication flow - Component rendering and user interactions - Cross-device storage functionality **Test Patterns:** - Use descriptive test names that explain the scenario - Mock Firebase services for isolated testing - Test business logic separately from UI components ## Comprehensive Code Documentation Pattern ### Self-Documenting Code Standard All code must be written with extensive inline documentation that explains **what**, **why**, and **how** to modify elements. Follow the JobValueCompass component pattern as the gold standard. ### Documentation Requirements #### 1. Component-Level Documentation ```tsx // --- // HOW TO EDIT THE SIZE OF THE WHOLE RADAR CHART? // --- // The size of the radar chart is controlled by two main things: // 1. The height of the container div (e.g. className="h-[350px]") // - This controls the vertical space for the chart. Increase/decrease the h-[XXXpx] value to make the chart area taller or shorter. // 2. The `outerRadius` prop on the component (e.g. outerRadius="60%") // - This controls the radius of the radar chart as a percentage of the container. Increase to make the chart fill more of the container, decrease for more padding. // // To make the chart bigger or smaller, change the value of the container's height // and/or the `outerRadius` prop. Both are set separately for mobile and desktop below. // --- ``` #### 2. Style Property Documentation Every style-related element must include comprehensive comments explaining: - **Purpose**: What the style does - **Values**: What values can be used - **Effect**: How changing it affects the appearance - **Examples**: Alternative values and their effects ```tsx
{/* backdrop-blur-xl: Applies a strong background blur. Change to "backdrop-blur-md" for less blur, or remove for no blur. bg-white/10: Sets a white background with 10% opacity. Change the number for more/less opacity. border border-white/20: Adds a border with 20% white opacity. Change to "border-black/10" for a different color/opacity. shadow-2xl: Applies a large shadow. Change to "shadow-lg" for a smaller shadow, or remove for no shadow. rounded-2xl: Rounds the corners. Change to "rounded-lg" for less rounding, or remove for square corners. p-6: Padding inside the container. Change to "p-4" for less padding, "p-8" for more. */}
``` #### 3. Interactive Element Documentation For components with user interaction, document: - **Function**: What the element does - **Customization**: How to modify behavior - **Styling**: How to change appearance - **State**: How it responds to different states ```tsx // --- STYLE ELEMENTS IN THIS COMPONENT --- // - fontSize: Controls the size of the category label text. Change the value (e.g. "10" or "12") to make labels smaller or larger. // - fill: Controls the color of the label text. Change "#374151" to any hex color for different text color. // - fontWeight: Controls the boldness of the label text. "600" is semi-bold; use "400" for normal, "700" for bold. // - fontFamily: Controls the font used for the labels. Change to any valid CSS font-family string. // - letterSpacing: Controls the spacing between letters. Adjust "-0.01em" for tighter/looser text. // - radius: Controls how far the labels are from the center of the chart. Increase for more space between chart and labels. // - xOffset: Controls horizontal offset for left/right labels. Adjust for fine-tuning label position. // ---------------------------------------- ``` #### 4. Responsive Design Documentation Document how elements behave across different screen sizes: ```tsx {isMobile ? ( // To change the mobile chart size, edit the h-[300px] class and/or outerRadius below
{/* h-[300px]: Height of the chart area. Increase/decrease for bigger/smaller chart. w-full: Full width. opacity-40: 40% opacity for the whole chart (makes it look "greyed out"). Change to "opacity-60" for less faded, "opacity-20" for more faded. */} ) : ( // To change the desktop chart size, edit the h-[350px] class and/or outerRadius below
)} ``` #### 5. Configuration Object Documentation For configuration objects, explain each property: ```tsx const categoryNames: Record = { // These control the display names for each category in the radar chart // Change the values on the right to customize how categories appear purpose: 'Purpose', // Shows as "Purpose" on the chart growth: 'Growth', // Shows as "Growth" on the chart compensation: 'Compensation', // Shows as "Compensation" on the chart // ... etc }; ``` #### 6. Complex Logic Documentation For complex calculations or logic, provide step-by-step explanations: ```tsx // Calculate angle from center const angle = Math.atan2(y - cy, x - cx); // Position label at fixed radius // Change these values to move labels closer/farther from the chart const radius = isMobile ? 65 : 110; const newX = cx + Math.cos(angle) * radius; const newY = cy + Math.sin(angle) * radius; // Smart anchoring to prevent cutoff // This logic determines text alignment based on position around the circle if (angleInDegrees > 60 && angleInDegrees < 120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Bottom labels } else if (angleInDegrees < -60 && angleInDegrees > -120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Top labels } // ... etc ``` ### Documentation Standards #### Required Documentation Blocks: 1. **File Header**: Brief description of component purpose 2. **HOW TO EDIT**: Major customization instructions at the top 3. **Style Elements**: Inline comments for every style property 4. **Configuration**: Explanation of all configurable values 5. **Logic**: Step-by-step explanation of complex operations 6. **Responsive**: Mobile vs desktop differences #### Documentation Format: - Use `// ---` separators for major sections - Use `/* */` for multi-line style explanations - Use `//` for single-line clarifications - Include specific examples with alternative values - Explain the visual/functional impact of changes #### Mandatory Elements to Document: - All Tailwind CSS classes with their purpose and alternatives - All props and their acceptable values - All configuration objects and their properties - All complex calculations or positioning logic - All responsive breakpoints and their differences - All interactive elements and their behaviors ### Benefits of This Pattern: - **Self-Sufficient**: Developers can modify without external documentation - **Educational**: Teaches CSS/styling concepts through examples - **Maintainable**: Changes are easier when effects are understood - **Collaborative**: Team members can quickly understand and modify code - **Future-Proof**: Code remains understandable months/years later ### Implementation Rule: Every component must be documented to the level where a developer unfamiliar with the codebase can: 1. Understand what each element does 2. Know exactly how to modify appearance/behavior 3. See examples of alternative configurations 4. Understand responsive behavior differences ## Responsive Code Structure Best Practices ### Preferred Approach: Mobile-First Responsive Classes Use Tailwind's responsive prefixes instead of JavaScript conditionals when possible: ```tsx // ✅ PREFERRED: Single component with responsive classes
``` ### When to Use JavaScript Conditionals: Only use separate mobile/desktop code blocks when: - **Fundamentally different layouts** are required - **Complex logic** differs significantly between devices - **Performance optimization** requires different components ### Structure for JS Conditionals (when necessary): ```tsx export const Component = () => { // --- SHARED CONFIGURATION --- const sharedProps = { /* common props */ }; // --- MOBILE CONFIGURATION --- const mobileConfig = { /* mobile-specific settings */ }; // --- DESKTOP CONFIGURATION --- const desktopConfig = { /* desktop-specific settings */ }; // --- RESPONSIVE LOGIC --- const isMobile = useMediaQuery('(max-width: 640px)'); const config = isMobile ? mobileConfig : desktopConfig; return (
{/* Single implementation using config */}
); }; ``` ### Avoid: - ❌ Duplicating entire component trees for different devices - ❌ Separate mobile/desktop returns with identical JSX - ❌ Hard-coded breakpoints in multiple places ### Benefits of Mobile-First Approach: - **Less code duplication** - **Easier maintenance** - **Better performance** (CSS-based vs JS-based) - **More flexible** (handles all breakpoints, not just 2) - **Future-proof** (new devices automatically supported) Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions. ## 🔄 CODEBASE REFACTORING INSTRUCTIONS ### Mobile-First Responsive Design + Self-Documenting Code Implementation **Target:** Transform the entire codebase to follow the JobValueCompass pattern established in `src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx` --- ## 📋 PHASE 1: AUDIT & PLANNING ### Step 1.1: Identify Components Requiring Refactoring Search for these patterns that need conversion: ```bash # Find JavaScript-based responsive conditionals grep -r "window.innerWidth" src/ grep -r "isMobile" src/ grep -r "useMediaQuery" src/ grep -r "typeof window" src/ # Find components with duplicate mobile/desktop code grep -r "if.*mobile" src/ -i grep -r "else.*desktop" src/ -i ``` ### Step 1.2: Component Priority List **High Priority (Core UI Components):** 1. Header.tsx 2. Logo.tsx 3. AssessmentForm.tsx 4. ResultsChart.tsx 5. All components in `/pages/` **Medium Priority (Feature Components):** 6. All components in `/components/auth/` 7. All components in `/components/ui/` 8. All components in `/components/storage/` **Low Priority (Utility Components):** 9. BackgroundWrapper.tsx 10. ErrorBoundary.tsx --- ## 📱 PHASE 2: MOBILE-FIRST CONVERSION PATTERNS ### Pattern A: Replace JavaScript Conditionals with Responsive Classes **❌ BEFORE (JavaScript-based):** ```tsx const isMobile = typeof window !== 'undefined' && window.innerWidth < 640; if (isMobile) { return (
{/* Mobile content */}
); } return (

`firestore.rules` - Database security rules - `storage.rules` - Storage security rules **Important Notes:** - Uses Firebase-first architecture (prefer Firebase over localStorage) - All Firebase operations include error handling - Security rules enforce user authentication for data access ## Testing Strategy **Test Organization:** - Unit tests: Business logic in `/utils/__tests__/` - Component tests: React components in `__tests__/` folders - Integration tests: Firebase operations in `/src/__tests__/firebase/` **Key Test Areas:** - Assessment scoring calculations (`calculationCore.test.ts`) - Firebase authentication flow - Component rendering and user interactions - Cross-device storage functionality **Test Patterns:** - Use descriptive test names that explain the scenario - Mock Firebase services for isolated testing - Test business logic separately from UI components ## Code Patterns & Best Practices **Component Documentation Standard:** Follow the JobValueCompass component pattern (`/src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx`) which exemplifies: - Comprehensive inline documentation explaining what, why, and how to modify - Responsive design with Tailwind classes instead of JavaScript conditionals - Clear examples of alternative configurations ### Documentation Requirements #### 1. Component-Level Documentation ```tsx // --- // HOW TO EDIT THE SIZE OF THE WHOLE RADAR CHART? // --- // The size of the radar chart is controlled by two main things: // 1. The height of the container div (e.g. className="h-[350px]") // - This controls the vertical space for the chart. Increase/decrease the h-[XXXpx] value to make the chart area taller or shorter. // 2. The `outerRadius` prop on the component (e.g. outerRadius="60%") // - This controls the radius of the radar chart as a percentage of the container. Increase to make the chart fill more of the container, decrease for more padding. // // To make the chart bigger or smaller, change the value of the container's height // and/or the `outerRadius` prop. Both are set separately for mobile and desktop below. // --- ``` #### 2. Style Property Documentation Every style-related element must include comprehensive comments explaining: - **Purpose**: What the style does - **Values**: What values can be used - **Effect**: How changing it affects the appearance - **Examples**: Alternative values and their effects ```tsx
{/* backdrop-blur-xl: Applies a strong background blur. Change to "backdrop-blur-md" for less blur, or remove for no blur. bg-white/10: Sets a white background with 10% opacity. Change the number for more/less opacity. border border-white/20: Adds a border with 20% white opacity. Change to "border-black/10" for a different color/opacity. shadow-2xl: Applies a large shadow. Change to "shadow-lg" for a smaller shadow, or remove for no shadow. rounded-2xl: Rounds the corners. Change to "rounded-lg" for less rounding, or remove for square corners. p-6: Padding inside the container. Change to "p-4" for less padding, "p-8" for more. */}
``` #### 3. Interactive Element Documentation For components with user interaction, document: - **Function**: What the element does - **Customization**: How to modify behavior - **Styling**: How to change appearance - **State**: How it responds to different states ```tsx // --- STYLE ELEMENTS IN THIS COMPONENT --- // - fontSize: Controls the size of the category label text. Change the value (e.g. "10" or "12") to make labels smaller or larger. // - fill: Controls the color of the label text. Change "#374151" to any hex color for different text color. // - fontWeight: Controls the boldness of the label text. "600" is semi-bold; use "400" for normal, "700" for bold. // - fontFamily: Controls the font used for the labels. Change to any valid CSS font-family string. // - letterSpacing: Controls the spacing between letters. Adjust "-0.01em" for tighter/looser text. // - radius: Controls how far the labels are from the center of the chart. Increase for more space between chart and labels. // - xOffset: Controls horizontal offset for left/right labels. Adjust for fine-tuning label position. // ---------------------------------------- ``` #### 4. Responsive Design Documentation Document how elements behave across different screen sizes: ```tsx {isMobile ? ( // To change the mobile chart size, edit the h-[300px] class and/or outerRadius below
{/* h-[300px]: Height of the chart area. Increase/decrease for bigger/smaller chart. w-full: Full width. opacity-40: 40% opacity for the whole chart (makes it look "greyed out"). Change to "opacity-60" for less faded, "opacity-20" for more faded. */} ) : ( // To change the desktop chart size, edit the h-[350px] class and/or outerRadius below
)} ``` #### 5. Configuration Object Documentation For configuration objects, explain each property: ```tsx const categoryNames: Record = { // These control the display names for each category in the radar chart // Change the values on the right to customize how categories appear purpose: 'Purpose', // Shows as "Purpose" on the chart growth: 'Growth', // Shows as "Growth" on the chart compensation: 'Compensation', // Shows as "Compensation" on the chart // ... etc }; ``` #### 6. Complex Logic Documentation For complex calculations or logic, provide step-by-step explanations: ```tsx // Calculate angle from center const angle = Math.atan2(y - cy, x - cx); // Position label at fixed radius // Change these values to move labels closer/farther from the chart const radius = isMobile ? 65 : 110; const newX = cx + Math.cos(angle) * radius; const newY = cy + Math.sin(angle) * radius; // Smart anchoring to prevent cutoff // This logic determines text alignment based on position around the circle if (angleInDegrees > 60 && angleInDegrees < 120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Bottom labels } else if (angleInDegrees < -60 && angleInDegrees > -120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Top labels } // ... etc ``` ### Documentation Standards #### Required Documentation Blocks: 1. **File Header**: Brief description of component purpose 2. **HOW TO EDIT**: Major customization instructions at the top 3. **Style Elements**: Inline comments for every style property 4. **Configuration**: Explanation of all configurable values 5. **Logic**: Step-by-step explanation of complex operations 6. **Responsive**: Mobile vs desktop differences #### Documentation Format: - Use `// ---` separators for major sections - Use `/* */` for multi-line style explanations - Use `//` for single-line clarifications - Include specific examples with alternative values - Explain the visual/functional impact of changes #### Mandatory Elements to Document: - All Tailwind CSS classes with their purpose and alternatives - All props and their acceptable values - All configuration objects and their properties - All complex calculations or positioning logic - All responsive breakpoints and their differences - All interactive elements and their behaviors ### Benefits of This Pattern: - **Self-Sufficient**: Developers can modify without external documentation - **Educational**: Teaches CSS/styling concepts through examples - **Maintainable**: Changes are easier when effects are understood - **Collaborative**: Team members can quickly understand and modify code - **Future-Proof**: Code remains understandable months/years later ### Implementation Rule: Every component must be documented to the level where a developer unfamiliar with the codebase can: 1. Understand what each element does 2. Know exactly how to modify appearance/behavior 3. See examples of alternative configurations 4. Understand responsive behavior differences ## Responsive Code Structure Best Practices ### Preferred Approach: Mobile-First Responsive Classes Use Tailwind's responsive prefixes instead of JavaScript conditionals when possible: ```tsx // ✅ PREFERRED: Single component with responsive classes
``` ### When to Use JavaScript Conditionals: Only use separate mobile/desktop code blocks when: - **Fundamentally different layouts** are required - **Complex logic** differs significantly between devices - **Performance optimization** requires different components ### Structure for JS Conditionals (when necessary): ```tsx export const Component = () => { // --- SHARED CONFIGURATION --- const sharedProps = { /* common props */ }; // --- MOBILE CONFIGURATION --- const mobileConfig = { /* mobile-specific settings */ }; // --- DESKTOP CONFIGURATION --- const desktopConfig = { /* desktop-specific settings */ }; // --- RESPONSIVE LOGIC --- const isMobile = useMediaQuery('(max-width: 640px)'); const config = isMobile ? mobileConfig : desktopConfig; return (
{/* Single implementation using config */}
); }; ``` ### Avoid: - ❌ Duplicating entire component trees for different devices - ❌ Separate mobile/desktop returns with identical JSX - ❌ Hard-coded breakpoints in multiple places ### Benefits of Mobile-First Approach: - **Less code duplication** - **Easier maintenance** - **Better performance** (CSS-based vs JS-based) - **More flexible** (handles all breakpoints, not just 2) - **Future-proof** (new devices automatically supported) Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions. ## 🔄 CODEBASE REFACTORING INSTRUCTIONS ### Mobile-First Responsive Design + Self-Documenting Code Implementation **Target:** Transform the entire codebase to follow the JobValueCompass pattern established in `src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx` --- ## 📋 PHASE 1: AUDIT & PLANNING ### Step 1.1: Identify Components Requiring Refactoring Search for these patterns that need conversion: ```bash # Find JavaScript-based responsive conditionals grep -r "window.innerWidth" src/ grep -r "isMobile" src/ grep -r "useMediaQuery" src/ grep -r "typeof window" src/ # Find components with duplicate mobile/desktop code grep -r "if.*mobile" src/ -i grep -r "else.*desktop" src/ -i ``` ### Step 1.2: Component Priority List **High Priority (Core UI Components):** 1. Header.tsx 2. Logo.tsx 3. AssessmentForm.tsx 4. ResultsChart.tsx 5. All components in `/pages/` **Medium Priority (Feature Components):** 6. All components in `/components/auth/` 7. All components in `/components/ui/` 8. All components in `/components/storage/` **Low Priority (Utility Components):** 9. BackgroundWrapper.tsx 10. ErrorBoundary.tsx --- ## 📱 PHASE 2: MOBILE-FIRST CONVERSION PATTERNS ### Pattern A: Replace JavaScript Conditionals with Responsive Classes **❌ BEFORE (JavaScript-based):** ```tsx const isMobile = typeof window !== 'undefined' && window.innerWidth < 640; if (isMobile) { return (
{/* Mobile content */}
); } return (
{/* Desktop content */}
); ``` **✅ AFTER (Mobile-first responsive):** ```tsx // Single implementation with responsive classes
{/* h-[300px] sm:h-[350px] lg:h-[400px]: Responsive height - h-[300px]: Mobile height (300px) - sm:h-[350px]: Tablet and up height (350px) - lg:h-[400px]: Desktop and up height (400px) p-4 sm:p-6: Responsive padding - p-4: Mobile padding (16px) - sm:p-6: Tablet+ padding (24px) To make bigger/smaller: - Increase heights: h-[350px] sm:h-[400px] lg:h-[450px] - Decrease heights: h-[250px] sm:h-[300px] lg:h-[350px] */} {/* Same content for all devices */}
``` ### Pattern B: Responsive Text Content **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx {isMobile ? "Short text" : "This is a longer descriptive text"} ``` **✅ AFTER:** ```tsx {/* Show different text based on screen size using responsive classes */} Short text This is a longer descriptive text ``` ### Pattern C: Responsive Component Props **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx

input.new_string:
## Component-Specific Notes

**Assessment Form Components:**
- `AssessmentForm.tsx` - Handles 1-5 satisfaction ratings with "bother level" for negative ratings
- `ImportanceForm.tsx` - Optional importance weighting (can be skipped)
- Both use local storage for persistence during assessment flow

**Results Components:**
- `JobValueCompass.tsx` - Main radar chart visualization (exemplary responsive design)
- `SatisfactionSpeedometer.tsx` - Circular progress indicator
- `CoachingInsights.tsx` - AI-generated personalized recommendations
- `DetailedResults.tsx` - Tabular breakdown of scores

**Chart Customization:**
The radar chart size is controlled by responsive Tailwind classes:
```tsx
// Container height affects chart size
className="h-[300px] sm:h-[350px] lg:h-[400px]"

// Chart radius as percentage of container
<RadarChart outerRadius="70%" />
```

## Security & Authentication

**Authentication Flow:**
1. User registration/login through Firebase Auth
2. Protected routes use `ProtectedRouteWrapper` component
3. User profile data stored in Firestore with proper security rules

**Data Protection:**
- Assessment data saved to Firebase only after user authentication
- Guest users can complete assessments (stored locally)
- No sensitive data in client-side code
- All API keys use VITE_ prefix for client-side exposure safety

## Development Workflow

**Before Making Changes:**
1. Run linting: `npm run lint`
2. Run tests: `npm test` or `npm run test:vitest`
3. Test responsive design at all breakpoints
4. Verify Firebase connection if working with backend features

**Common Issues & Solutions:**
- **Build failures**: Check TypeScript errors with `npm run build`
- **Chart rendering**: Ensure ResponsiveContainer wraps Recharts components
- **Authentication**: Use Firebase emulators for local development
- **Responsive design**: Use Tailwind classes instead of JavaScript conditions

**Performance Considerations:**
- Lazy load chart components (already implemented)
- Minimize JavaScript breakpoint detection
- Use Vite's fast refresh for development
- Monitor bundle size with build outputs

# CLAUDE.md This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository. # JobJoy Assessment Platform Development Guide ## Project Overview This is a React/TypeScript job satisfaction assessment platform with Firebase backend. Users complete multi-dimensional assessments and receive personalized coaching insights through interactive radar chart visualizations. **Key Technologies:** - Frontend: React 18 + TypeScript + Vite - UI: Tailwind CSS + Radix UI components (shadcn/ui) - Charts: Recharts for radar visualization - Backend: Firebase (Auth, Firestore, Storage) - Testing: Jest + Vitest + React Testing Library - State: React Context + TanStack Query ## Core Philosophy - **Pre-phase Planning**: Always formulate and discuss plans before implementation - **Minimal Code**: Lines of code = Technical debt. Write less, achieve more - **Security First**: Never expose secrets, always implement proper authentication - **Type Safety**: Use TypeScript with strict typing across all projects - **Modular Architecture**: 150-line file limit, extract when approaching limit ## Common Development Commands **Development:** ```bash npm run dev # Start development server (Vite) at http://localhost:5173 npm run dev:prod # Start dev server with production config ``` **Building:** ```bash npm run build # Build for production (automatically detects environment) npm run build:dev # Build with development config npm run build:prod # Build with production config npm run preview # Preview production build locally ``` **Testing:** ```bash npm test # Run Jest tests npm run test:watch # Run Jest in watch mode npm run test:vitest # Run Vitest tests npm run test:vitest:watch # Run Vitest in watch mode ``` **Linting & Code Quality:** ```bash npm run lint # Run ESLint ``` **Deployment:** ```bash npm run deploy # Build and deploy to Firebase (full deploy) npm run deploy:hosting # Build and deploy only hosting ./deploy.sh # Run deployment script with status output ``` **Firebase Emulators:** ```bash firebase emulators:start # Start all Firebase emulators # Emulator ports (from firebase.json): # - Auth: 9797 # - Firestore: 8785 # - Storage: 9798 # - Hosting: 5001 # - UI: 4700 ``` ## Project Architecture **Core Application Flow:** 1. **Landing Page** (`/pages/Index.tsx`) - Welcome and start assessment 2. **Assessment Phase** (`/pages/FirstStep.tsx`) - Job satisfaction rating (1-5 scale) 3. **Importance Phase** (`/pages/SecondStep.tsx`) - Importance weighting (optional, can be skipped) 4. **Results** (`/pages/ResultsEnhanced.tsx`) - Radar chart visualization and coaching **Key Architecture Patterns:** **State Management:** - React Context for auth (`/context/AuthContext.tsx`) - TanStack Query for server state - Local storage utilities for assessment data persistence - Cross-device storage system for assessment continuity **Component Organization:** ``` src/ ├── components/ # Reusable UI components │ ├── auth/ # Authentication-related components │ ├── results/ # Results visualization components │ ├── storage/ # File upload/download components │ └── ui/ # Base UI components (shadcn/ui) ├── pages/ # Route components (one per route) ├── context/ # React contexts (Auth, Firebase) ├── firebase/ # Firebase service functions ├── hooks/ # Custom React hooks ├── utils/ # Utility functions └── types/ # TypeScript type definitions ``` **Assessment Scoring System:** - Core logic in `src/utils/calculationCore.ts` - Produces scores from -88 to +88 - Handles both weighted (with importance) and unweighted modes - Includes "bother level" impact for negative satisfaction **Mobile-First Responsive Design:** - Uses Tailwind responsive classes (`sm:`, `lg:`) instead of JavaScript breakpoints - JobValueCompass component exemplifies best responsive patterns - Prevent scrolling on assessment pages with specific container patterns ## Firebase Integration **Environment Variables Required:** ```bash VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY=your-api-key VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN=your-auth-domain VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID=your-project-id VITE_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET=your-storage-bucket VITE_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID=your-messaging-sender-id VITE_FIREBASE_APP_ID=your-app-id ``` **Key Firebase Files:** - `src/firebase/config.ts` - Firebase app initialization - `src/firebase/auth.ts` - Authentication functions - `src/firebase/firestore.ts` - Database operations - `src/firebase/storage.ts` - File storage operations - `firestore.rules` - Database security rules - `storage.rules` - Storage security rules **Important Notes:** - Uses Firebase-first architecture (prefer Firebase over localStorage) - All Firebase operations include error handling - Security rules enforce user authentication for data access ## Testing Strategy **Test Organization:** - Unit tests: Business logic in `/utils/__tests__/` - Component tests: React components in `__tests__/` folders - Integration tests: Firebase operations in `/src/__tests__/firebase/` **Key Test Areas:** - Assessment scoring calculations (`calculationCore.test.ts`) - Firebase authentication flow - Component rendering and user interactions - Cross-device storage functionality **Test Patterns:** - Use descriptive test names that explain the scenario - Mock Firebase services for isolated testing - Test business logic separately from UI components ## Code Patterns & Best Practices **Component Documentation Standard:** Follow the JobValueCompass component pattern (`/src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx`) which exemplifies: - Comprehensive inline documentation explaining what, why, and how to modify - Responsive design with Tailwind classes instead of JavaScript conditionals - Clear examples of alternative configurations **Mobile-First Responsive Patterns:** - Use Tailwind responsive classes: `h-[300px] sm:h-[350px] lg:h-[400px]` - Avoid JavaScript breakpoint detection when possible - Test at mobile (375px), tablet (768px), and desktop (1024px) sizes **Assessment Data Flow:** 1. Data stored in localStorage during assessment (`/utils/storageUtils.ts`) 2. Cross-device storage for assessment continuity (`/utils/crossDeviceStorage.ts`) 3. Firebase storage for authenticated users 4. Calculation engine transforms raw ratings into -88 to +88 scores **UI Component Guidelines:** - Use shadcn/ui components from `/components/ui/` folder - Follow existing button, form, and layout patterns - Maintain consistent spacing with Tailwind classes - All interactive elements must work on touch devices #### 2. Style Property Documentation Every style-related element must include comprehensive comments explaining: - **Purpose**: What the style does - **Values**: What values can be used - **Effect**: How changing it affects the appearance - **Examples**: Alternative values and their effects ```tsx

Configuration Object Documentation For configuration objects, explain each property: ```tsx const categoryNames: Record = { // These control the display names for each category in the radar chart // Change the values on the right to customize how categories appear purpose: 'Purpose', // Shows as "Purpose" on the chart growth: 'Growth', // Shows as "Growth" on the chart compensation: 'Compensation', // Shows as "Compensation" on the chart // ... etc }; ``` #### 6. Complex Logic Documentation For complex calculations or logic, provide step-by-step explanations: ```tsx // Calculate angle from center const angle = Math.atan2(y - cy, x - cx); // Position label at fixed radius // Change these values to move labels closer/farther from the chart const radius = isMobile ? 65 : 110; const newX = cx + Math.cos(angle) * radius; const newY = cy + Math.sin(angle) * radius; // Smart anchoring to prevent cutoff // This logic determines text alignment based on position around the circle if (angleInDegrees > 60 && angleInDegrees < 120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Bottom labels } else if (angleInDegrees < -60 && angleInDegrees > -120) { anchor = 'middle'; // Top labels } // ... etc ``` ### Documentation Standards #### Required Documentation Blocks: 1. **File Header**: Brief description of component purpose 2. **HOW TO EDIT**: Major customization instructions at the top 3. **Style Elements**: Inline comments for every style property 4. **Configuration**: Explanation of all configurable values 5. **Logic**: Step-by-step explanation of complex operations 6. **Responsive**: Mobile vs desktop differences #### Documentation Format: - Use `// ---` separators for major sections - Use `/* */` for multi-line style explanations - Use `//` for single-line clarifications - Include specific examples with alternative values - Explain the visual/functional impact of changes #### Mandatory Elements to Document: - All Tailwind CSS classes with their purpose and alternatives - All props and their acceptable values - All configuration objects and their properties - All complex calculations or positioning logic - All responsive breakpoints and their differences - All interactive elements and their behaviors ### Benefits of This Pattern: - **Self-Sufficient**: Developers can modify without external documentation - **Educational**: Teaches CSS/styling concepts through examples - **Maintainable**: Changes are easier when effects are understood - **Collaborative**: Team members can quickly understand and modify code - **Future-Proof**: Code remains understandable months/years later ### Implementation Rule: Every component must be documented to the level where a developer unfamiliar with the codebase can: 1. Understand what each element does 2. Know exactly how to modify appearance/behavior 3. See examples of alternative configurations 4. Understand responsive behavior differences ## Responsive Code Structure Best Practices ### Preferred Approach: Mobile-First Responsive Classes Use Tailwind's responsive prefixes instead of JavaScript conditionals when possible: ```tsx // ✅ PREFERRED: Single component with responsive classes
``` ### When to Use JavaScript Conditionals: Only use separate mobile/desktop code blocks when: - **Fundamentally different layouts** are required - **Complex logic** differs significantly between devices - **Performance optimization** requires different components ### Structure for JS Conditionals (when necessary): ```tsx export const Component = () => { // --- SHARED CONFIGURATION --- const sharedProps = { /* common props */ }; // --- MOBILE CONFIGURATION --- const mobileConfig = { /* mobile-specific settings */ }; // --- DESKTOP CONFIGURATION --- const desktopConfig = { /* desktop-specific settings */ }; // --- RESPONSIVE LOGIC --- const isMobile = useMediaQuery('(max-width: 640px)'); const config = isMobile ? mobileConfig : desktopConfig; return (
{/* Single implementation using config */}
); }; ``` ### Avoid: - ❌ Duplicating entire component trees for different devices - ❌ Separate mobile/desktop returns with identical JSX - ❌ Hard-coded breakpoints in multiple places ### Benefits of Mobile-First Approach: - **Less code duplication** - **Easier maintenance** - **Better performance** (CSS-based vs JS-based) - **More flexible** (handles all breakpoints, not just 2) - **Future-proof** (new devices automatically supported) Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security over clever solutions. ## 🔄 CODEBASE REFACTORING INSTRUCTIONS ### Mobile-First Responsive Design + Self-Documenting Code Implementation **Target:** Transform the entire codebase to follow the JobValueCompass pattern established in `src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx` --- ## 📋 PHASE 1: AUDIT & PLANNING ### Step 1.1: Identify Components Requiring Refactoring Search for these patterns that need conversion: ```bash # Find JavaScript-based responsive conditionals grep -r "window.innerWidth" src/ grep -r "isMobile" src/ grep -r "useMediaQuery" src/ grep -r "typeof window" src/ # Find components with duplicate mobile/desktop code grep -r "if.*mobile" src/ -i grep -r "else.*desktop" src/ -i ``` ### Step 1.2: Component Priority List **High Priority (Core UI Components):** 1. Header.tsx 2. Logo.tsx 3. AssessmentForm.tsx 4. ResultsChart.tsx 5. All components in `/pages/` **Medium Priority (Feature Components):** 6. All components in `/components/auth/` 7. All components in `/components/ui/` 8. All components in `/components/storage/` **Low Priority (Utility Components):** 9. BackgroundWrapper.tsx 10. ErrorBoundary.tsx --- ## 📱 PHASE 2: MOBILE-FIRST CONVERSION PATTERNS ### Pattern A: Replace JavaScript Conditionals with Responsive Classes **❌ BEFORE (JavaScript-based):** ```tsx const isMobile = typeof window !== 'undefined' && window.innerWidth < 640; if (isMobile) { return (
{/* Mobile content */}
); } return (
{/* Desktop content */}
); ``` **✅ AFTER (Mobile-first responsive):** ```tsx // Single implementation with responsive classes
{/* h-[300px] sm:h-[350px] lg:h-[400px]: Responsive height - h-[300px]: Mobile height (300px) - sm:h-[350px]: Tablet and up height (350px) - lg:h-[400px]: Desktop and up height (400px) p-4 sm:p-6: Responsive padding - p-4: Mobile padding (16px) - sm:p-6: Tablet+ padding (24px) To make bigger/smaller: - Increase heights: h-[350px] sm:h-[400px] lg:h-[450px] - Decrease heights: h-[250px] sm:h-[300px] lg:h-[350px] */} {/* Same content for all devices */}
``` ### Pattern B: Responsive Text Content **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx {isMobile ? "Short text" : "This is a longer descriptive text"} ``` **✅ AFTER:** ```tsx {/* Show different text based on screen size using responsive classes */} Short text This is a longer descriptive text ``` ### Pattern C: Responsive Component Props **❌ BEFORE:** ```tsx

## Quick Reference

**File Path Patterns:**
- Pages: `/src/pages/[PageName].tsx`
- Components: `/src/components/[ComponentName].tsx`
- UI Components: `/src/components/ui/[component-name].tsx`
- Utils: `/src/utils/[utilName].ts`
- Firebase: `/src/firebase/[service].ts`
- Types: `/src/types/` or inline with components
- Tests: `__tests__/` folders adjacent to tested files

**Common Tailwind Patterns:**
```tsx
// Standard responsive heights
className="h-[280px] sm:h-[350px] lg:h-[400px]"

// Standard responsive padding
className="p-4 sm:p-6 lg:p-8"

// Standard responsive text
className="text-sm sm:text-base lg:text-lg"

// Standard responsive spacing
className="space-y-4 sm:space-y-6"

// Standard responsive grid
className="grid grid-cols-1 sm:grid-cols-2 lg:grid-cols-3 gap-4 sm:gap-6"
```

**Important Files to Understand:**
- `src/utils/calculationCore.ts` - Assessment scoring algorithm
- `src/components/results/JobValueCompass/JobValueCompass.tsx` - Example of excellent responsive design
- `src/context/AuthContext.tsx` - Authentication state management
- `src/firebase/firestore.ts` - Database operations
- `firestore.rules` - Database security configuration

Remember: Always prioritize code clarity, maintainability, and security. Use the existing patterns in JobValueCompass as the gold standard for new components.
